entries.meaning: A line at the side of something.
Something that is additional or extra or that exists around the edges or margins of a main item.
examples: She started the business as a sideline to her regular work and it ended up becoming the greater source of income.
Soup need not be just a sideline to a meal; if you like, it can be the main course.

entries.meaning: A line for hobbling an animal by connecting the fore and the hind feet of the same side.
(sports) A line defining the side boundary of a playing field. Used in Canadian football, field lacrosse and basketball.
examples: Synonym: (in rugby union, rugby league and association football) touchline

entries.meaning: (sports) Usually in the plural: the area outside the playing field beyond each sideline.
examples: The coach stood on the sidelines and bellowed commands at the team.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) The outside or perimeter of any activity.
examples: She installed the whole fixture while he simply watched from the sidelines.

entries.meaning: (Canada) A secondary road, especially a byroad at right angles to a main road.

verbs.description: sideline (third-person singular simple present sidelines, present participle sidelining, simple past and past participle sidelined)

entries.meaning: (sports, transitive) To place on the sidelines; to bench or to keep someone out of play.
examples: The coach sidelined the player until he regained his strength.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove or keep out of circulation or out of the focus.
examples: The illness sidelined him for weeks.
